title: Solid Oxide Cells: from 3D Microstructure to Comprehensive Quantification
content: Performance and durability of solid oxide cell (SOC) electrodes are closely linked to their porous microstructure properties and the microstructure evolution during the cell's lifetime. Thus, comprehensive characterization of three-dimensional (3D) microstructures is essential for SOC electrode optimization. Over the years, Ga+ FIB-SEM tomography has become an extremely important technique for the three-dimensional reconstruction of solid oxide cell microscopic structures with nanometric resolution (voxel size: âˆ¼ 20 - 40 nm3) [1]. Nevertheless, the size of the material volume accessible by Ga-based FIB-SEMs in a reasonable timeframe is limited to dozens of microns cubed. This limitation may restrict the amount of quantitative information extracted from a small material volume, which can make the data not representative for the entire cell. For the latest designs of graded SOC, Ga+ FIB serial-sectioned volumes may not capture the representative volume elements (RVEs) of more complex cells. The advent of Plasma FIB-SEM (PFIB-SEM) microscopes, which offer accessed material volumes thousandfold larger than those of traditional FIB-SEMs [2], along with the latest implementations of automated serial sectioning, multidetector SEM imaging techniques, and SEM auto-functions, make PFIB-SEM an ideal platform for investigating SOC microstructures and other porous materials.
